matched.matchReason: Direct match - Both findings describe the same reflected XSS vulnerability where user input from the 'name' parameter is directly embedded into a JavaScript string within a script tag without proper encoding or sanitization. Both identify the bypassing of a blacklist filter using special characters. The actual finding provides detailed POC demonstrating three successful XSS payloads that bypass the filter, confirming the vulnerability identified in the expected findings.

extra.title: Server Information Disclosure in HTTP Headers
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - The application discloses Werkzeug/3.1.3 and Python/3.13.3 version information in the Server header, which is genuine information disclosure that could assist attackers in reconnaissance. This is a legitimate finding not covered by expected findings.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers on Homepage
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - Missing critical security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Content-Security-Policy, Strict-Transport-Security) provides defense-in-depth protection. This is a legitimate finding that represents a real security gap not covered by expected findings.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - Duplicate/related to the MEDIUM severity finding above, documenting the same missing security headers issue at a different severity classification. This is a legitimate finding.

extra.title: Broken Link to XSS Challenge - 404 Error
extra.assessment: Valid finding - The /xss25 endpoint referenced in the homepage returns 404, indicating incomplete implementation. While not a critical security vulnerability, it represents a broken link. This is a legitimate application-level finding not covered by expected findings.

extra.title: Missing Cache-Control Headers on Homepage
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - Absence of Cache-Control headers could allow caching of dynamic content. This is a legitimate security best practice finding not covered by expected findings.

extra.title: Malformed HTML - Invalid type Attribute on Anchor Tag
extra.location: Homepage HTML - anchor tag in challenge links
extra.assessment: Valid finding - The anchor tag contains an invalid 'type=text' attribute which violates HTML5 specification. While primarily a code quality issue, malformed HTML can indicate incomplete sanitization. This is a legitimate finding not covered by expected findings.

extra.title: Unclosed HTML Tags - Missing </article> Tag
extra.assessment: Valid finding - The article tag is opened but never closed, representing malformed HTML structure. This affects rendering and accessibility. This is a legitimate code quality finding not covered by expected findings.

extra.title: Missing Authentication on Challenge Endpoints
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - The application returns HTTP 404 instead of proper 401/403 for challenge endpoints, indicating broken access control. This is a high-severity finding representing a broken access control vulnerability (OWASP A01:2021) not covered by expected findings.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Challenge Names Exposed in Root Page HTML
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - Challenge names and URL patterns are exposed in the HTML source code, revealing application structure and enabling attacker reconnaissance. This is a legitimate information disclosure finding not covered by expected findings.

extra.title: Broken Form Functionality - Missing Form Action and Method
extra.assessment: Valid finding - The form is missing critical 'action' and 'method' attributes, rendering it non-functional. While not a direct security vulnerability, it indicates incomplete implementation that could correlate with other security gaps. This is a legitimate finding not covered by expected findings.

extra.title: X-XSS-Protection Header Disabled on /xss32 Endpoint
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - The application explicitly sets X-XSS-Protection header to '0', disabling browser XSS protection on the same endpoint that contains the reflected XSS vulnerability. This compounds the XSS vulnerability by actively removing a defense mechanism. This is a legitimate finding not covered by expected findings.
